abstract.text: An object that specifies the position and orientation of an item in the physical environment.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: To track the static positions and orientations of real or virtual objects relative to the camera, create anchor objects and use the
method to add them to your AR session.

Adding an anchor to the session helps ARKit to optimize world-tracking accuracy in the area around that anchor, so that virtual objects appear to stay in place relative to the real world. If a virtual object moves, remove the corresponding anchor from the old position and add one at the new position.
Some ARKit features automatically add special anchors to a session. World-tracking sessions can add
, and
objects if you enable the corresponding features; face-tracking sessions add
objects.
In addition to creating your own
instances to track the real-world positions of your virtual content, you can also subclass
to associate custom data with anchors you create. Ensure that your anchor classes behave correctly when ARKit updates frames or saves and loads anchors in an
Anchor subclasses must fullfill the requirements of the
protocol. ARKit calls
(on a background thread) to copy instances of your anchor class from each
to the next. Your implementation of this initializer should copy the values of any custom properties your subclass adds.
Anchor subclasses must also adopt the
protocol. Override
and
to save and restore the values your subclass’ custom properties when ARKit saves and loads them in a world map.
Anchors are considered equal based on their
property.
Only anchors that do not adopt
are included when you save a world map.

abstract.text: Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
An object that specifies the position and orientation of an item in the physical environment.
A unique identifier for the anchor.
Creates a new anchor object with the specified transform and a descriptive name.
Creates a new anchor object with the specified transform.
A descriptive name for the anchor.
The unique identifier of the session that owns this anchor.
A matrix encoding the position, orientation, and scale of the anchor relative to the world coordinate space of the AR session the anchor is placed in.
Support for custom anchor subclasses.
Initializes a new anchor by copying custom information from another anchor.
An anchor that tracks the position and orientation of an App Clip Code in the physical environment.
An anchor that tracks the position and movement of a human body in the rear-facing camera.
An object that provides environmental lighting information for a specific area of space in a world-tracking AR session.
An anchor for a unique face that is visible in the front-facing camera.
A video image captured as part of a session with position-tracking information.
An anchor that identifies a geographic location using latitude, longitude, and altitude data.
An anchor for a known image that ARKit detects in the physical environment.
An anchor for a physical object that ARKit detects and recreates virtually using a polygonal mesh.
An anchor for a real-world 3D object that ARKit detects in the physical environment.
An anchor for another user in multiuser augmented reality experiences.
An anchor for a 2D planar surface that ARKit detects in the physical environment.
The object that manages the major tasks associated with every AR experience, such as motion tracking, camera passthrough, and image analysis.
Adds the specified anchor to be tracked by the session.
An interface for objects that track the location of real-world objects or locations.
The state in a world-tracking AR session during which a device maps the user’s position in physical space and proximity to anchor objects.
Integrate iOS device camera and motion features to produce augmented reality experiences in your app or game.
Control rendering of your app’s virtual content on top of a camera feed.

doc://com.apple.arkit/documentation/ARKi.title: Displaying an AR Experience with Metal

abstract.text: Use SpriteKit to place two-dimensional images in 3D space in your AR experience.
Use SceneKit to add realistic three-dimensional objects to your AR experience.
Check whether your app can use ARKit and respect user privacy at runtime.

doc://com.apple.arkit/documentation/ARKi.title: Verifying Device Support and User Permission

abstract.text: Encodes the receiver using a given archiver.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
